factoid: Prince Vasíli asked “Didn’t Hippolyte tell you?”
Prince Vasíli turned to his son.
Prince Vasíli seized the little princess’ arm as if she would have run away.
Prince Vasíli had just managed to catch the little princess.
Prince Vasíli asked whether Hippolyte told him how Hippolyte was pining for the dear princess.
Prince Vasíli asked whether Hippolyte told him how the princess showed him the door.
Prince Vasíli said “Oh, she is a pearl among women, Princess.”
Prince Vasíli turned to Princess Mary.
Mademoiselle Bourienne seized the opportunity of joining in the general recollections when Paris was mentioned.
Mademoiselle Bourienne inquired whether it had been long since Anatole had left Paris.
Mademoiselle Bourienne inquired how Anatole had liked Paris.
Anatole answered Mademoiselle Bourienne very readily.
Anatole looked at Mademoiselle Bourienne with a smile.
Anatole talked to Mademoiselle Bourienne about her native land.
When Anatole saw the pretty little Bourienne, Anatole concluded he would not find Bald Hills dull.
Anatole thought “Not at all bad!”
Anatole examined Mademoiselle Bourienne.
Anatole thought “Not at all bad, that little companion!”
Anatole hoped Mademoiselle Bourienne would bring her along with her when they were married.
Mademoiselle Bourienne is charming.
The old prince dressed leisurely in his study.
The old prince was frowning.
The old prince was considering what he was to do.
The arrival of the visitors annoyed the old prince.
The old prince asked himself “What are Prince Vasíli and that son of his to me?”
The old prince said Prince Vasíli is a shallow braggart.
The old prince said his son is a fine specimen.
The old prince was angered because the visitors revived an unsettled question he always tried to stifle.
The unsettled question was whether he could ever bring himself to part from his daughter and give her to a husband.
The old prince never directly asked himself that question.
The old prince knew he would have to answer it justly.
Justice clashed with his feelings and with the possibility of life.
Life without Princess Mary was unthinkable to the old prince.
The old prince thought “And why should she marry?”
The old prince thought “To be unhappy for certain.”
The old prince thought “There’s Lise, married to Andrew—a better husband one would think could hardly be found nowadays.”
The old prince wondered if Lise is contented with her lot.
The old prince wondered who would marry Marie for love.
The old prince thought Marie would be taken for her connections and wealth.
The old prince wondered if there are no women living unmarried, and even happier for it.
The old prince was Prince Bolkónski.
The old prince was dressing.
The old prince thought the question he was always putting off demanded an immediate answer.
Prince Vasíli had brought his son with the evident intention of proposing.
Prince Vasíli would probably ask for an answer today or tomorrow.
Prince Vasíli’s birth and position in society were not bad.
The old prince said “Well, I’ve nothing against it.”
The old prince said “but he must be worthy of her.”
The old prince said “And that is what we shall see.”
The old prince repeated “That is what we shall see!” aloud.
The old prince entered the drawing room with his usual alert step.
The old prince glanced rapidly around the company.
The old prince noticed the change in the little princess’ dress.
The old prince noticed Mademoiselle Bourienne’s ribbon.
The old prince noticed Princess Mary’s unbecoming coiffure.
The old prince noticed Mademoiselle Bourienne’s smile.
The old prince noticed Anatole’s smile.
The old prince noticed the loneliness of his daughter amid the general conversation.
The old prince thought “Got herself up like a fool!”
The old prince looked irritably at his daughter.
Princess Mary is shameless, and Prince Vasíli ignores her.
The old prince went straight up to Prince Vasíli.
Prince Vasíli said “Well! How d’ye do? How d’ye do? Glad to see you!”
Prince Vasíli said “Friendship laughs at distance.”
Prince Vasíli said “Here is my second son; please love and befriend him.”
The old prince surveyed Anatole.
The old prince said “Fine young fellow! Fine young fellow!”
The old prince said “Well come and kiss me,” and offered his cheek.
Anatole kissed the old prince.
Anatole looked at the old prince with curiosity and perfect composure.
Anatole was waiting for a display of the eccentricities his father had told him to expect.
The old prince sat down in his usual place in the corner of the sofa.
The old prince drew up an armchair for Prince Vasíli.
The old prince pointed to the armchair and began questioning Prince Vasíli about political affairs and news.
The old prince seemed to listen attentively to what Prince Vasíli said.
The old prince kept glancing at Princess Mary.
